analytic.title: To the right Noble and vertuous his singuler good Lady, the Lady Anne Countesse of Warwicke.
analytic.author: Hake, Edward

monogr.title: An oration conteyning an expostulation : as well with the Queenes Highnesse faithfull subiects for their want of due consideration of Gods blessings enioyed by meanes of her Maiestie: as also with the vnnaturall english for their disloyaltie and vnkindnesse towards the sam their soueraygne. At the first pronounced vpon the Queenes Maiesties birthday in the Guyldhall of the burrowe of Newe Windsore, by Edward Hake of Grayes Inne Gent. then Mayer of the same burrowe: and now newly imprinted this xvij. day of Nouember, in the xxx. yeere of the Queenes Highnesse most happie raigne
monogr.author: Hake, Edward

div.head: To the right Noble and vertuous his singuler good Lady, the Lady Anne Countesse of Warwicke.
div.p:
THE time being now growen long (right noble Countesse) since J first endeuoured to shewe my self vnto my honorable good Lorde and your Ladiship in some acceptable course of seruice, and finding alwaies some one or other vnkind let thereunto: I haue now at length, as one ouer wearyed with the fruitlesse expectation of my hopelesse mynd (euen to the vpbrayding as it were of myne ill happe) desperatly attempted to present your Honor with this slight and slender booke: not that I reckon it a sufficient supplye of the thing I want and desired, but rather as an occasion to shewe how greatly grieued J remayne that my happe hath not bene all this while to doe better, especially vnto such and so noble a
〈…〉 it self vnder the respect of my zeale and dutifull meaning: protesting that it hath not proceeded from me as the fruite of an ydle brayne, but as the true effect of a most zealous mynd and well affected heart. And so hoping your Honor will conceiue of it, J forbeare the further lengthening of this my rude Epistle.

closer.dateline: From London this ioyfull xvij. day of Nouember, beginning the xxx. yeere of her Maiesties most happie Raigne.
closer.signed: Your Honorable La. in all humble seruice: Edward Hake.
